title: Deceased Spouse's Credit Card Debt
question: my husband lived in another State two years prior to his death recently.
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Probate court,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers: You would need to have the matter adjudicated in a probate court since he has died. But you are responsible for 1/2 of the CP estate - both assets and debts acquired during the marriage. Please seek legal assistance. Chances are very possible that the creditors, once they discovery you were married, will try to seek payment from your estate.
If your name is on the card as well, then you are responsible; if not then they have to go to court to assert their rights to collect the debt from your property.

California is a community property state such that both assets and debts incurred during marriage are community. The answer to your question may depend where your husband was living and what the terms of the credit card debt were, meaning were you a co-signor, etc, and or the status of your marriage when the debt was incurred. If the debt is community property debt, incurred during your marriage, then you may be responsible for it.
